content.description:
The Crux for me was getting past the first bolt. Trust your feet, grab tiny crystals, and keep your weight from going to both feet at the same time and you will really find this climb a true delight! Top gets a tad easier but still in the 11a range. Do in the shade. 

Book: A desperately thin slab move off the dirt leads to easier climbing above. Bring some TCUs to supplement the bolts. 



This route is off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. The start to the climb is the third bolted line from the arete as you are going left. Walk off or be lowered down.

The best landmark one can find below the first bolt there is a left leaning thin/slopey ramp that you can use to start the climb. 


Mixed, finger size, TCU

A right-facing corner with a nice crack in it.  This is a good intro climb for new leaders.  Plenty of protection.

Right under the large steel electrical tower.
Standard Rack up to 2 inches.  Gear anchor at the top.  I suppose many tie off to the tower above, but I think that is verboten.

The Crux for me was just getting off the ground. This is a great slab climb that is a real test piece to lead. Trust your feet, grab tiny crystals, and keep your weight from going to both feet at the same time and you will really find this climb a true delight!

This route is off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. The start to the climb is the second bolted line from the arete as you are going left. Walk off or be lowered down.
6 Bolts protect the route plus one section half way up the climb for some pro. Bolted anchor at top.

This wall has a black streak flanked by two white streaks.  The route follows three bolts to the left of these streaks. 
  
 The right-hand finish (5.9, FA: Ostrander, Oliver, 1988) is better, and is more direct.

Right below the large steel electrical tower.
Three bolts.  Gear anchor at the top.  There are bolt holes indicating the once-presence of bolts, but none now.  I suppose many tie off to the tower above, but I think that is verboten.

The crux is at the very top where you have a technical bulge to climb before reaching the anchor. I made it through the climb well until I got to this section and found it really hard. I would change the rating of the climb to an 11d due to the bulge move. I have yet to climb this through clean and don't plan on leading it any time soon!

This route is found off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. You find the start by looking just right of Fatty Bolger 11a to the obvious line of bolts going up the arete. The initial wall on the right of the arete has no climbing routes as another indication that your there. You can walk off this climb or be lowered back down.
6 bolts protect the entire route...there could be a few more if you ask me. Anchor is bolts at the top.

The left side of the Fatty Bolger crag has four lower angle sport climbs.  They are all good introductory leads.  This is the hardest of them and can be quite tough if you make a conscious effort to limit yourself to holds along the bolt line.  It can be made easier by straying left and right at times.  These are some of the best and only introductory sport climbs in the area, and although they are fairly low-angle, they are worthwhile.  Despite being low-angle, they aren't the friction slabs that are so common in this area; there are holds.

Left side of Fally Bolger crag, second line left of the gully.
4 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor

This climb starts with a pretty mellow crack, gets a little more intense when you have to leave the crack to a bolt, peaks with a fun pull over a bulge and then lets you down easy with a twenty foot runout on easy friction.  A very fun climb.

This is the first climb right of the mossy gully that divides the two halves of Fatty Bolger.
A few finger to hand-sized cams and nuts for the initial crack, then two quickdraws.  There's a two-bolt anchor at the top (no rap hangers or chains), and a straightforward walk-off.

Climb the corner to the first bolt, then break out left up the arete 


Bolts

I found the climb so sustained that I couldn't begin to feel for the crux specifically. The top gets a bit easier. The climb as a whole is exceptional and I highly recommend doing it.

This route is just right of Rumours 10a it follows the bolted line that goes up and to the right a bit before going straight up. It is the first line of bolts right of the crack start for Rumours. Lower down or walk off
7 bolts protect the route with an anchor at the top
